report.report_description: Air pollution is one of the most important environmental threats to urban populations and while all people are exposed, pollutant emissions, levels of exposure, and population vulnerability vary across neighborhoods. Exposures to common air pollutants have been linked to respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, cancers, and premature deaths.
report.report_text: Categories based on whether the most recent neighborhood value falls among the best, middle or worse performing third of all NYC neighborhoods. NYC is divided into 42 neighborhoods based on the United Hospital Fund (UHF) approach of aggregating zip code areas to approximate Community Planning Districts.
report.report_footer: More data and information on Asthma and the Environment can be found on the NYC Tracking Portal (www.nyc.gov/health/tracking) and on EpiQuery(www.nyc.gov/health/epiquery). The tracking program is part of the National Environmental Public Health Tracking Network (www.cdc.gov/EPHTracking).
report_data_source: 1. United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Air Quality System (AQS) Data
2. New York City Community Air Survey
3. USEPA Air Quality System; Krewski D, et al. (2009) HEI Research Report 140. Health Effects Institute, Boston, MA
4. USEPA Air Quality System; Ito K et al. (2007) J Expo Sci Environ Epidemiol 17:S45–S60
5. USEPA Air Quality System; Moolgavkar SH (2000) Inhal Toxicol 12(Supp 4):75–90; Zanobetti etal.(2009) Environ Hlth 8:58. doi:10.1186/1476-069X-8-58
6. US EPA Air Quality System; Ito K et al (2011) Environ Hlth Persp, 119(4):467-473
7. USEPA Air Quality System; Huang Y et al. (2005) Environmetrics 16:547–562
8. US EPA Air Quality System; Silverman RA, Ito K (2010) J Allergy Clin Immun 125(2):367–373
9. New York City Bureau of Vital Statistics; United States Census
10. New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS); US Census
11. New York Metropolitan Transportation Council Best Practice Model

report_content.report_topic_description: Estimated annual average concentrations calculated from a model that used NYC Community Air Survey measurements.

report_topic_data.indicator_description: The New York City (NYC) Heat Vulnerability Index (HVI) is a measure of how the risk of heat-related illness or death differs across neighborhoods. Neighborhood risk factors that increase heat- vulnerability in NYC are: less home air conditioning, less green space, hotter surface temperatures, and more residents who are low-income or non-Latinx Black. Differences in these risk factors across neighborhoods are rooted in past and present racism.
report_topic_data.source_description: New York City Community Air Survey
